nodes.text: Infant social attachment to the mother is driven primarily by contact comfort (physical softness, warmth, and tactile contact) rather than by nursing or food-related secondary drive associations
Psychologists historically emphasized primary drives (hunger, thirst, pain, sex) and treated love or affection as derived secondary drives associated with drive reduction

Neonatal and infant rhesus macaque monkeys are an appropriate experimental model to analyze basic affectional variables because they are more mature at birth and show comparable development of nursing, contact, clinging, perception, fear, and learning to humans

Method: Constructed two mother surrogates for infant monkeys: a soft, warm terry-cloth-covered wooden surrogate providing contact comfort and a wire-mesh surrogate providing postural support and nursing but reduced contact comfort; some surrogates lactated while others did not

Method: Experimental design included dual-mother condition (cloth and wire surrogates attached to cage), single-cloth and single-wire control groups, automated recording of time spent on each surrogate, fear tests, open-field tests, modified Butler baby-box visual exploration tests, and long-term retention testing up to at least 185 days

Result: Infants overwhelmingly preferred the cloth surrogate over the wire surrogate regardless of which surrogate provided milk; contact time on cloth mother far exceeded time on wire mother and this preference persisted for at least 165 days

Result: Single-cloth and single-wire mother control groups showed no differences in milk intake or weight gain, but wire-mother infants produced softer stools suggesting psychosomatic effects; wire mother was biologically adequate but psychologically inept

Evidence: In fear-producing tests (moving toy) and strange open-field situations infants sought the cloth surrogate as a haven of safety and base of operations, reducing emotionality indices (vocalization, crouching, rocking, sucking) compared with absence or presence of wire surrogate, independent of nursing condition

Evidence: Modified Butler baby-box visual exploration tests showed infants responded strongly to cloth mother and to other infant monkeys but not to wire mother or empty box; this selectivity persisted in retention tests up to 185 days

Result: Affectional bonds to the cloth surrogate were highly resistant to extinction and showed long-term retention and motivated puzzle-solving and persistent approach behaviors in post-separation and retention tests, regardless of feeding condition

Control evidence: Monkeys reared without surrogates and introduced to cloth and wire mothers at 250 days initially displayed fear and avoidance but within days developed strong contact preferences for the cloth surrogate, though intensity was lower than infants mothered from birth

Claim: Nursing and food provision are insufficient to account for the formation and persistence of infant affectional bonds; the primary function of nursing as an affectional variable may be to ensure frequent body contact

Conclusion: Contact comfort is a basic, primary variable in the development of affectional responses and security in infant monkeys, and this challenges drive-reduction theories that explain attachment primarily by food association

Implication: Techniques and findings permit systematic study of other affectional variables (postural support, rocking, clinging, maternal sounds, visual features such as the face), timing of maternal deprivation, and father-infant or infant-infant affection

Limitation: Some variables remain untested or only suggested (e.g., face responsiveness, role of rocking, imprinting-like visual factors), and human neonates have motor limitations that make direct experimental translation limited; comparisons with real mother attachment require further definitive tests
